{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 422 of the Energy Conservation and Production Act

text.#text: The

header.#text: Grants to eligible housing and nonprofit organizations
Grants to eligible housing and nonprofit organizations

text.#text: The purposes of this section are—

to expand the number of low-income, single-family and multifamily homes that receive energy
			 efficiency retrofits;

to promote innovation and new models of retrofitting low-income homes through new Federal
			 partnerships with covered organizations that leverage donations, donated
			 materials, volunteer labor, homeowner labor equity, and other private
			 sector resources;

to assist the covered organizations in demonstrating, evaluating, improving, and replicating widely
			 the model low-income energy retrofit programs of the covered
			 organizations; and

to ensure that the covered organizations make the energy retrofit projects undertaken by the
			 covered organizations with awarded funds self-sustaining by the time grant
			 funds have been expended.
In this section, the term

external-xref.#tail: of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986

has an established record of constructing, renovating, repairing, or making energy efficient an
			 aggregate quantity of not less than 250 owner-occupied, single-family or
			 multifamily homes for low-income households, either directly or through
			 affiliates, chapters, or other direct partners (using the most recent year
			 for which data are available).

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall make grants to covered organizations through a national competitive process for
			 use in accordance with this section.

text.#text: Not later than 90 days after the closing date established by the
A grant under this section may be used to—
conduct energy efficiency audits;

perform cost-effective retrofit and related weatherization activities, including purchase of energy
			 efficient materials and supplies;
conduct training activities and provide ongoing technical assistance;
provide information to homeowners on proper maintenance and energy savings behaviors;

conduct data collection, measurement, and verification activities to facilitate program monitoring,
			 oversight, evaluation, and reporting;
manage and administer the grant (up to a maximum of 10 percent of the total grant); and
obtain and conduct such other materials and activities as the
The amount of a grant provided under this section shall not exceed $5,000,000.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall issue
			 guidelines to implement the grant program established under this section.

Weatherization Enhancement, and Local Energy Efficiency Investment and Accountability Act

text.#text: Congress finds that—

term.#tail: ) and the Weatherization Assistance Program for Low-Income Persons established under
) have proven to be beneficial, long-term partnerships among Federal, State, and local partners;

part A of

text.#text:
the SEP and the WAP have been reauthorized on a bipartisan basis over many years to address
			 changing national, regional, and State circumstances and needs, especially
			 through—
the
the
the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: State Energy Efficiency Programs Improvement Act of 1990
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: State Energy Efficiency Programs Improvement Act of 1990

text.#text: the
the
the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007

text.#text: the SEP, also known as the

was first created in 1975 to implement a State-based, national program in support of energy
			 efficiency, renewable energy, economic development, energy emergency
			 preparedness, and energy policy; and
the WAP—
was first created in 1976 to assist low-income families in response to the first oil embargo;

has become the largest residential energy conservation program in the United States, with more than
			 7,100,000 homes weatherized since the WAP was created;

saves an estimated 35 percent of consumption in the typical weatherized home, yielding average
			 annual savings of $437 per year in home energy costs;

has created thousands of jobs in both the construction sector and in the supply chain of materials
			 suppliers, vendors, and manufacturers who supply the WAP;

returns $2.51 in energy savings for every Federal dollar spent in energy and nonenergy benefits
			 over the life of weatherized homes;

serves as a foundation for residential energy efficiency retrofit standards, technical skills, and
			 workforce training for the emerging broader market and reduces residential
			 and power plant emissions of carbon dioxide by 2.65 metric tons each year
			 per home; and
has decreased national energy consumption by the equivalent of 24,100,000 barrels of oil annually;

the WAP can be enhanced with the addition of a targeted portion of Federal funds through an
			 innovative program that supports projects performed by qualified nonprofit
			 organizations that have a demonstrated capacity to build, renovate,
			 repair, or improve the energy efficiency of a significant number of
			 low-income homes;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Inspector General of the Department of
			 Energy

text.#text: reports of the

through the history of the WAP, the WAP has evolved with improvements in efficiency technology,
			 including, in the 1990s, many States adopting advanced home energy audits,
			 which has led to great returns on investment; and

as the home energy efficiency industry has become more performance-based, the WAP should continue
			 to use those advances in technology and the professional workforce.
